facts.text: Appellant (plaintiff) and respondent (defendant) married at Patan on April 20, 1942, according to Hindu rites of the Jain Community.
Parties lived in Bombay in a two-room flat with appellant's family; appellant's mother mostly at Patan.
Son Kirit born on September 10, 1945.
Mahendra, a friend of the family, began living with the family in Bombay flat in 1946 after discharge from army.
Appellant left for England on business on January 8, 1947.

During appellant's absence, respondent became intimate with Mahendra; wrote letter Ex. E to Mahendra in April 1947 from Patan while staying with mother-in-law; letter admitted by respondent's counsel.
Appellant returned to Bombay on May 20, 1947; on first night, his bed made in hall by father; slept apart from wife.
On May 21, 1947 morning, appellant's father handed him Ex. E; appellant recognized wife's handwriting.
Appellant gave letter to photographer for copies on May 21; confronted wife that evening; she denied writing.
On May 23, 1947, showed photostat to wife; she admitted writing, said Mahendra better man, loved him.
On morning of May 24, 1947, wife said packed luggage to go to Jalgaon for cousin's marriage; appellant offered car and Rs.100; she refused, left by afternoon train with everything.
Appellant's mother had left for Patan with son some days before May 24, 1947.
Wife never returned to Bombay or wrote from Jalgaon.
Solicitor's letter dated July 15, 1947 to wife charging intimacy with Mahendra, demanding child back; no reply.
In November 1947, appellant's mother informed from Patan that wife expected in Bombay; appellant sent telegram 'Must not send Prabha. Letter posted.' to father-in-law.
Carbon copy of letter Ex. C dated November 13, 1947 to father-in-law expressing surprise, demanding wife's repentance letter before return; denied receipt by respondent.
Appellant's father wrote Ex. D on November 15, 1947 to respondent's father insisting on appellant's consent before sending wife.
No answer to telegram or letters.
May 1948, appellant went to Patan, asked wife to return if repents for Mahendra relations; she said decided not to in Nov 1947 due to pressure.
Later 1948, appellant went to Patan as wife had typhoid; she showed no desire to return.
April-May 1949, third interview at Jalgaon; wife refused return even for child.
Suit filed July 4, 1951 for dissolution on ground of desertion since May 24, 1947 for over four years, custody of child.
Respondent's written statement Feb 4, 1952: denied intimacy, said compelled to leave by husband's treatment; always willing to return; relatives approached husband who refused.
Respondent and son lived with appellant's family at Patan for over four months off and on.
Trial before Tendolkar J.: single issue on desertion; plaintiff examined himself; defendant, father Popatlal, cousin Bhogilal; trial judge found desertion, decreed divorce March 7, 1952, no costs.
Appeal No. 66 of 1952: Division Bench (Chagla CJ, Bhagwati J) allowed appeal Aug 22, 1952, dismissed suit with costs; held no desertion, husband's letter terminated any desertion.
Leave to appeal to SC refused by another Division Bench; special leave granted by SC.

legal_issues.text: Whether the defendant deserted the plaintiff for a continuous period of over four years prior to the filing of the suit under section 3(1)(d) of the Bombay Hindu Divorce Act, 1947.

petitioner_arguments.text: Defendant deserted since May 24, 1947 without reasonable cause and against his will; intimacy with Mahendra proved by Ex. E; admitted writing and love; left with all belongings; no return despite offers; animus deserendi present.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Bombay Hindu Divorce Act s.3(1)(d); desertion requires factum of separation and animus deserendi

petitioner_arguments.text: Solicitor's letter July 15, 1947 was to shock family into persuading return; always willing to take back if repents.

respondent_arguments.text: Husband's treatment after return from England made life unbearable, compelled her to leave May 24, 1947; no intimacy or confession; always ready and willing to return; relatives approached husband who refused; lived with in-laws at Patan.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: No desertion; constructive desertion by husband; solicitor's letter showed husband's refusal

respondent_arguments.text: Telegram Nov 13 and father's letter Nov 15 prevented return; Ex. E mere platonic love.

court_reasoning.text: Ex. E suspicious, shows amorous correspondence unworthy of faithful wife, consciousness of guilt; justified husband's suspicion and demand for repentance; but not proof of sexual intercourse.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Wife's explanation disingenuous; trial court right to discredit.

court_reasoning.text: Departure May 24 consistent with shame after discovery, not necessarily permanent desertion; equivocal without clear animus deserendi.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Burden on petitioner to prove beyond reasonable doubt; happenings consistent with both versions.

court_reasoning.text: Solicitor's letter July 15, 1947 shows husband not desiring to keep wife, not affirming marriage; no allegation of desertion; inconsistent with petitioner's claim of willingness.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Deserted spouse must be willing to resume; presumption of continuance rebutted.

court_reasoning.text: Telegram Ex. B and Ex. D peremptory, negative willingness; Ex. C dubious.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Husband more sinned against but must prove all elements.

court_reasoning.text: Respondent's relatives' evidence corroborates willingness to return; petitioner's uncorroborated; stays at Patan inconsistent with desertion.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No proof of continuous desertion for 4 years; plaintiff fails burden.

holdings.text: No desertion proved by plaintiff; essential ingredients - factum of separation with animus deserendi without consent and without reasonable cause for continuous 4 years - not established beyond reasonable doubt.

precedents_cited.relevance: Corroboration required as precaution in divorce cases.
Desertion not single act but course of conduct; purpose revealed by acts.
Act of departure significance from purpose.
Party intending to end cohabitation commits desertion.
Desertion requires factum and animus; not always physical leaver.
Desertion must persist throughout period; petitioner's attitude matters.
Guilty party not always leaver; look to conduct.

statutes_cited.name: Bombay Hindu Divorce Act, 1947
statutes_cited.relevance: Ground of divorce for desertion for continuous 4 years without reasonable cause and without consent; definition of desertion.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; agreed with High Court Appellate Bench that no desertion proved; suit for dissolution dismissed.

key_quotes.text: "Desertion is the separation of one spouse from the other, with an intention on the part of the deserting spouse of bringing cohabitation permanently to an end without reasonable cause and without the consent of the other spouse"
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Definition from Rayden summarizing desertion elements.

key_quotes.text: "In its essence desertion means the intentional permanent forsaking and abandonment of one spouse by the other without that others consent, and without reasonable cause. It is a total repudiation of the obligations of marriage."
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: The letter Ex. E "reads like a love letter written by a girl to her paramour."
key_quotes.speaker: lower_court
key_quotes.significance: Trial court's view on incriminating letter upheld in part.

key_quotes.text: "Our client states that under the events that have happened, our client has become entitled to obtain a divorce and our client does not desire to keep you any longer under his care and protection."
key_quotes.speaker: petitioner
